Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Review Sessions
Lectures were live, but I attended asynchronously for most of the semester because I had another live class at the same time.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We learned about congenital heart defects (CHDs) and the current and future ways to treat it. We discussed tissue engineered vascular grafts and the immune response to biomaterials. The final project was to come up with a new design or approach to treating CHDs.
Learned about congenital heart defects, worked with other classmates to think of possible treatments
Very broad overview of the BME knowledge necessary to develop a tissue-engineered vascular graft; the class is problem-based, which means that it ends up being highly interdisciplinary.

I gained a lot of knowledge about the biological specifics of congenital heart defects and various medical solutions. However, I also learned so much about the process of drug discovery and design, and improved upon my skills in scientific discussion, research, and writing.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: Professor Humphrey is an incredible and engaging professor. He explains things clearly and welcomes all discussion/questions. He is approachable, enthusiastic, and flexible with students. The students have a lot of input in the course, and he welcomes feedback and suggestions. The content itself is also very interesting. It is one of the only classes where students get to discuss current and future treatments. The direct medical applications makes it much more relevant. The exams are fair and the homework assignments (short essays or math problems) are helpful for learning the material. Also, the guest speakers were very interesting.

Weaknesses: The course could use a bit more organization. We followed the syllabus, but it would have been helpful to have a review sheet with the information we were responsible for knowing. Also, the course is very backloaded. We had a 10 page paper + presentation + final exam at the very end of the semester. Together, those assignments made up 65% of our grade. It would have been nice to either reduce this workload or reduce the grade weight of these assignments.
Was a really good class! Didn't have much bio background going in, but Professor Humphrey really explains

Strengths: Prof. Humphrey does a great job presenting material in a clear, organized way and addressing people's questions; he also fostered a really supportive learning environment and did his best to make the class feel like a team despite the weirdness of virtual learning. I think the seminar format is great, especially since the vast majority of intro STEM courses are huge, impersonal lectures. Weaknesses: None to speak of.
Great great course, could seem kind of random at times but then we pulled it all together at the end. Very flexible and good for learning! Fun environment, even virtually

This course is very strong. The syllabus is great. The only weaknesses I felt this semester particularly pertain to the situation of the pandemic in that I think the course would have benefited from more of the usual hands on and in person elements but I think Professor Humphrey did an amazing job adapting where he could.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The professor used a running word document with notes from class (like a whiteboard). It was helpful to have those notes. He also always posted class notes on Canvas so students would be able to review the material. 

For the final exam, we did the multiple choice section in the Zoom chat (private). This was unnecessarily stressful. It would have been better to do the multiple choice on Canvas quizzes so that we could distribute our limited time as we please. The written parts of the midterm and final were fair, and we had plenty of time to complete and upload our work.

Posting the notes ahead of time (for the most part) was very helpful, as was Professor Humphrey's structuring of the class in a way that made it easy (and, in fact, necessary) to ask questions and engage with other students to complete assignments.

I think that professor Humphrey did the absolute best given the circumstances. I do believe that the course could have benefited from the in person components however, this was not possible and I still feel i am taking away HUGE lessons and skills from the class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes

Yes! This is a fun and interesting class with a relatively light workload. Many non-engineering majors also seem to enjoy this course. Professor Humphrey is very engaging and welcomes all majors. If you are interesting in tissue engineering and medical devices/treatments, take this course!
Yes! Professor Humphrey is so good at explaining and making sure material sticks.

Yep! Both for BME/STEM people and others. Very accessible introduction to the field, and the breadth is helpful too because you're not locked into one area when it comes time to develop the eventual "design" part of the course as your final.
yes it was one of the best classses ive taken

YES. I recommend this course and Professor Humphrey to ANY or ALL yale college students not just those in BME. This is a field where interdisciplinary thought can go a long way in project planning and innovative ideas.
